No. 1 Indian Day School,

R.R. No. 3, Wallaceburg Ont.
Sept. 12th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Smith,

As usual, upon the opening of school after the long vacation, there are certain minor repairs to be made and improvements to be attended to. I would kindly request that the Indian Dept grant authority to have the following done:

1. The bricks on the school doors repaired.
2. The wood for the teacher's residence split. There is approximately enough wood to last the greater part of the winter.
3. A seat placed on the privy toilet and a galvanized iron urinal installed in the basement, together with adequate for the 40 sq. ft. closet.

Would it be possible to have a kitchen built at the rear of the teacher's residence? There is absolutely no ventilation in the one downstairs room of the residence so it contains only one window.

Sincerely,

[Signature]
Not stifling almost, in winter, even
so the great doors are so grated that
it is almost unbearable trying to live
in it.

Trusting you will give these matters
your kind consideration, I remain,

Very truly yours,
Harriette H. Macpherson.
Inclosed find letter just received from Mrs. Mariette McPherson, teacher, of the No.1 Indian Day School, Halpole Island, which speaks for itself, asking for minor repairs and improvements. With reference to the first three items, I would recommend that they be granted. As to whether it be possible to have a kitchen built at the teacher's residence? This matter is well and truly explained in the letter. There is only one very small room down stairs, and I recommend that if it is at all possible, that a kitchen be built as requested.

J.M. McLennan, Esq.,
Postmaster & Secretary,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 17, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a communication from the teacher of the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School in which she requests that some minor repairs be made and that a kitchen be built at the rear of the teachers' residence.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have the knobs on the school doors repaired, also the seat repaired in the boys' toilet and a galvanized urinal installed. You should also arrange to have the wood for the teachers' residence split into proper stove lengths. We note the teacher states that there is approximately enough wood on hand to last the greater part of the coming winter. When the wood is split, it should be properly stored or piled. No unnecessary expense should be incurred in having the above work done, and you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expense. Please arrange to have the above work carried out as soon as possible.

Relative to the request of the teacher to have a kitchen built, I have to ask that you will state the approximate size of the kitchen required, and give an estimate of the cost of the materials and labour. You should also state how you would propose having the work carried out, and if you could arrange to have same done by day labour under the charge of a competent foreman - you to purchase all materials. Please furnish this information as soon as possible, and when same is received, consideration will then be given as to whether the erection of the kitchen can be authorised or not.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Thos. Paul, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing a minute of the council of the Walpole Island band recommending that two wooden horses be supplied to be used in the cleaning of the stove pipes at the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department does not see the necessity for providing equipment of this nature. It is considered that for this work, which is only required at long intervals, a stand could be erected, using packing boxes or some other similar equipment. The Department is not prepared to authorize the building of the two wooden horses.

Ottawa, August 5, 1928.

Sir:

A communication has been received from the teacher of the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School, in which she requests that certain painting and papering be carried out at the teachers' residence. She states that the new addition to the residence has been fitted with windows and doors in the old building, with the result that the wall paper has been torn down and in some places the wall is bare. I have to request that you will furnish, at the earliest possible date, an estimate of the cost of having the painting and decorating required by the teacher carried out and state how you would recommend that the work be done. The Department is anxious to have the residence portion of the building placed in a good condition. You might state, also, how the work in the erection of the new addition is proceeding and when it will be completed.

The teacher states, further, that the interior and exterior of the classroom portion of the building is badly in need of paint; that the outside has not been painted since 1914 and the ceilings inside have never been painted. Please report also on this painting, giving an estimate of the cost of the material and labour required and state how you would propose, if the work is authorized, that it should be carried out.

The teacher has requested certain furnishings for the two new rooms, viz., linoleum for the kitchen, a small rug for the bedroom, curtains, a couch bed and six chairs. She also requests you to give us an estimate of the cost, and, if the purchase is authorized, you will receive the necessary authority later.

You might discuss with Mrs. Macpherson the matter of the painting required. In the painting of the exterior and interior of the day school portion of the building urgent or could it be left over until next year? Your early reply, giving the information requested regarding this matter, is desired, in order that this work can be completed before the school re-opens after the present summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKinnon,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Thos. Paul, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.

Ottawa, September 14, 1926.

Sir:

With reference to requisition dated the 12th instant for supplies for the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School, I beg to say that you may purchase 12 balls yarn, 5 pairs knitting needles, 6 spools white thread, 2 packages needles, 6 skeins coloured thread, 20 yards lace, 15 yards muslin, 2 card buttons, 10 yards ribbon and 1 package darning needles. The above supplies should be purchased at as reasonable a cost as possible.

In forwarding this requisition, the teacher requested new sheets, pillow covers and bedspreads. Please let me know the number of these articles at present in the teachers' residence and their condition. If you consider new ones necessary, you should state the number and approximate cost. On receipt of your reply, the teacher's request in this regard will receive further consideration.

Yours obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

I am writing to inform you that Mr. Riggsfield expects to take up his residence on Walpole Island and thus be available whenever we need to consult him in matters relative to the school work. The present arrangement is most unsatisfactory. According to the fiscal year report, the agent was the school. The former agent always called regularly to see that all was going smoothly. Now there is a great deal of work necessary in connection with a day school of 75 pupils. Mr. Riggsfield never calls; it is most difficult to locate, as he seldom visits his office here and never comes when we telephone. Furthermore, we do not feel any sense of being handled. We go to Fort Edward to see him, although we have had to do so already.

Might I draw your attention to the following requests which have been made to Mr. Riggsfield but to date have brought no results:

Sir;-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7 inst., No 40-1-5 Re teachers report.

I might say that up till Dec. 21st I firmly believe that I averaged two calls a week to No 1 School, the two weeks following I was confined to my house with an attack of the "Flu", from Jan 3rd to the present date I have been in the office every day except Sundays, not over a half a mile from the School, have talked to the Senior teacher at intervals during this period, also I have a phone in my residence so what had they needed me on any pressing emergency I was available.

In a letter under date of Jan 11th I have dealt with the question of toilets for teachers personal use.

Regards to the wheel barrow when I placed the order there was none in stock, after ordering from wholesale it seemed much longer than usual for delivery, it came during the time I was confined with the "Flu" and the dealer forwarded it to Walpole Island where it remained at the Public dock for some time where they must surely have seen it, needing to pass it while going to and coming from the Algoma Ferry, as soon as I arrived at the office I had it delivered to the School house.

As for the kitchen sink and metal jacket for pump I have no recollection of them requesting me for such.

I was at the School again yesterday and they brought up the toilet question again, but did not ask for kitchen sink or metal jacket for pump, if they request from me a sink and metal jacket for pump I shall honor the dept with my report, they have mentioned the fact to me that they need no recommendation from me to see what they want, it has been brought to my attention in the past month or six weeks that they keep very irregular School hours they appear to have no set time for calling school in the morning recess or at noon hour, always take at least one hour and a half for noon when the school regulations specify only one hour, recently it has been brought to my attention that there are children living within one half mile of school who have not attended school during this term nor have not been reported as absentee's on monthly report, and when I spoke to the teachers about these children they were aware of the fact that they were not attending school, it has been reported to me that
there are other children not being reported for which I am as yet unable to confirm.

I am trying to get a check on conditions at this school also a list of children who should be attending. I am sorry to say that the teachers do not seem so inclined to co-operate.

If you will please refer to a former letter of mine covering the last School report you will see that I did not feel like recommending the adoption of the report as submitted as I wanted to get a further report of school hours as held daily at No. 1 School, also the non-attendance of pupils of school age which are not being reported on the monthly report to the Truant Officer.

I am Sir of the opinion that for harmony to prevail there should be complete co-operation between Agent and Teachers.

Your Obedient Servant,

Agent Walpole Reserve.

P.O. Box 3, Wallaceburg, Ont.
March 16th 1921

Mr. Russell Perrin,
Indian Education Office,
Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Perrin,

As another school year draws to a close, there are certain things which we who are so vitally interested in the school and the Indians of Walpole Island wish to draw to your attention. Reports on trivial matters in connection with the school, e.g., the great good to your health while the more worthwhile matters are overlooked. Please treat this letter as official or unofficial when convenient.

The wood for the school stove or indoor furnaces. The wood supplied is 3' long. This year, more than ever before, those having the contract to supply this wood have brought huge sticks, some just the trunks of trees, some trunks or hearts of the trunk with wood chopped off. The sticks weigh on an average 5 lbs each. It is almost physically impossible for any woman to keep the fires fed. We have to lift these sticks and throw...
them into the stove approximately 12 to 15 sticks a day at the fires used in building at both morning and afternoon recesses and at noon hour. During very cold weather we fill up the stoves at 4 o'clock. We drew the agent's attention to this want and asked him to see to it. It was split before being delivered also asked the man who supplied it if they were smaller wood, explaining how hard it was to lift. But no attention was paid to our request. There are about 40 cords of this wood piled in the yard too heavy to lift, while we keep burning the lumber wood scattered throughout the yard. This is not smaller wood be delivered to the school.

Early last fall we requested and the Dept. granted new toilets for the teacher's residence. To date these toilets have never been supplied. Meanwhile the two teachers and 16 pupils, both white and Indians have one toilet divided into 3 compartments but with the same pit underneath. The excuse for non-delivery was that the ground was frozen too hard to dig a pit although gravel was being dug in the cemetery next the school. Now there is no frost left in the ground.

A year or two ago the farmer's salary was increased to $100 a year on condition that he scrub once a month and clean the windows. The
School has not been scrubbed since Christmas and then only with a broom and cold water. It was filthy condition last week. One room was practically scrubbed for parasitic to being nourished. But the whole building should be thoroughly cleaned at Hampton where duty is to be done. That is done - the agent's teacher.

There has been an epidemic of sickness - severe coughing and vomiting among the school children at this school. They report only children attending (one day only). While here we only average 2-3 between the two teachers. Wed March 6 the Agent and Teacher decided to close the school, as the doctor says this "virus" is infecting through the plants to keep it from spreading. Should the school population be exposed to this disease, i.e., send home all pupils suspected of having it, be infected?

In the past the Dept. has hardly granted permission to buy each year, new swing rope for the school swings which are wooden ones erected over to repair a good and becoming quite unsafe would it be possible to have a steel frame and chain swings erected - regular playground equipment. It would be less expensive in the end.
as it would eliminate the practice of buying new sewing rope each year. There are 70 children attending here in the summer and the smaller ones do love to sewing. There are about 25 children, more or less, who for various reasons cannot attend school on the Reserve. We gave the list to the Agent and Truant Officer, who visited all the homes and found that in the majority of cases it would be advisable and the parents were willing that the children be sent to a residential school. Mr. Elgin is full but Shingwauk would accept some. No doubt you will have received the Agent's report on this but I again forward the list of children from this section of the Island. If you contemplate sending them away, please they go immediately before spring weather makes living conditions most disagreeable and they love the idea of education. Would like if anyone from here is sent with them to put in an application for the position of delivering them to a given destination.

Otherwise all is well. There is an Entrance Class of 3 pupils. Six of the children are taking violin or piano.
lessons and are making good progress with their school work.

Would it be possible to have our quarterly cheque forwarded in order to reach here before the end of the month. We have been requested to attend the Ontario Education Association meeting in Toronto, Easter week—April 1st-6th—and would like to have our cheque before we go.

Thanking you, I remain,

Very truly Yours,
Harriette Macpherson.

P.S.
Re the report or complaint about "Billie"—the goat. He is a small black and white goat given to the school children as a mascot. The school children raised him on a little land are most attached to him. He is kept tethered in a field beside the school yard, upon permission from the Indian owner. This is no bother absolutely. The complaint received was from the owner of a police dog which killed several pet rabbits here at the school. When he knew we were annoyed by retaliation by having a complaint put up against the goat, he didn't at all trouble if we ever did or not, saying anonymously that a complaint could be entered.
Ottawa, March 21st, 1929.

Indian Affairs

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, referring to various matters in connection with the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School.

Relative to the size of the wood supplied for the use of the school, the Department is taking this matter up with Mr. Agent Highfield. A cheque was sent yesterday to Walter Ross for supplying, piling and sawing wood. On his account you have certified that the work was satisfactorily done, and it is, therefore, presumed you refer to the wood that was purchased from Allan Isaac in December last, for the furnace. We have requested the Agent to see that the wood is split into sizes easy to handle.

We are also requesting the Agent to have a toilet for the teachers' residence erected as soon as possible, to engage into the janitor's services and to have the schoolroom thoroughly scrubbed and the windows washed during the coming Easter holidays. We are also requesting him to report regarding the cost of erecting swings of the type mentioned by you.

It is noted that the school was closed by order of the doctor on account of an epidemic of whooping cough, but that it has been reopened. No child having a contagious disease should be permitted to attend. If in any case you are aware that a child has, or you have strong reasons to suspect a child of having a contagious disease, you should not permit him or her to attend during the period of illness.

Cheques in payment of the salary of yourself and Mrs. MacDougall for the current quarter will be sent early next week.

Relative to the list of children which you enclosed as not attending school and whom you recommend be placed in residential schools, I have to say that all of these cases have already been drawn to the attention of the Department by Mr. Agent Highfield. The Department regrets that there are no vacancies for these children at either Mount Elgin or Shingwauk Home, Sault Ste. Marie, until after the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

A. J. MacKenzie

In further reference to your letter of the 3rd ultimo, referring to various matters in connection with the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School, I have to say:

(1) Relative to the size of the wood supplied for the use of the school furnace, the contract for supplying this wood was let at the time of the school fair last fall in the presence of the former Agent, Mr. Paul, and Mr. Saxsmith, and was delivered by the same man as supplied the wood to the No. 2 school, and the teacher of that school has spoken favorably of the quality of this wood. I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 12, 1929, #40-1-5 in reference to the well water at No.1 school being impure. In reply I beg to say that about a week before I received your letter I asked Dr. Cathcart the medical health officer to examine the water and report Dr. Cathcart called at the school and as soon as he could be available for the purpose he would have it analyzed and let us have a report as soon as I receive his report I will forward it to the Department also on the advisability of having the well cleaned. I always think it advisable to have a surface well cleaned at least once a year. The top of the well is quite tight it has a cement top except a small opening where the pump goes in that is covered with two inch plank and the pump bolted to them these plank could be covered with galvanized iron and possibly make it a little tighter. I have always understood that a surface well has to have some opening for air or the water will get stale and have a very bad odor.

The first complaint I received of the well being bad was early one morning Mrs. Macpherson called up and said the pump wouldn't work. I immediately secured the services of the Truant officer and we found the top off the well and the pump on the ground as we could see nothing wrong with it we put it back in again and worked as good as any pump and the water seemed to be all right to both myself and Mr. Wright (the Truant Officer) as there seemed to be some dirt floating on top. I ask the medical health officer to make an analysis.

J.D. Mclean

Dear Mrs. Highfield,

As the Christmas season is near, I am writing to draw your attention to plans for the Indian children's Christmas. It is customary for the Indians to save up money to be used to purchase suitable books, gifts, toys, etc., for the school children. Usually we have been helped through the year to spend a certain amount on the first store at Hanna, Saskatchewan. We are allowed a certain amount each year to purchase supplies for the school. However, this year, due to the present economic situation, it may not be possible for us to purchase the usual amount of supplies before the end of the year.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Walpole Island Agency.

The well at No. 1 school has been condemned; it is only eight feet deep. I imagine there is a surface seepage which has contaminated the water. I believe if the well were deepened and a cement top put on, good water might be obtained.

Mr. McPherson requests that the following may, in a war case for the well, be provided: North America, Ontario, Canada and the world. She also requests that one kettle, forty-five cups and forty-five spoons be supplied for hot lunch purposes to pupils who cannot go home at noon. If this request is considered, it will be necessary to furnish similar equipment for the No. 2 school.

The boys' closet at No. 1 school requires a new lid on the outside of box, also the closet door rehung and window fitted reed. Both No. 1 and 2 schools should have two coats of paint next summer.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McCookin, in a report on his recent inspection of the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School, states that the well has been condemned. This well is only 8 feet deep, and, no doubt, surface seepage has contaminated the water. The Inspector suggests that if the well were deepened and a cement top put on good water might be obtained. Please report regarding this well, stating the cost of having it deepened and a cement top put on, and whether you would recommend that the work be carried out.

The Inspector also states that the boys' closet requires a new lid on the outside of box and the closet door rehung and window light replaced. You should arrange to have this closet put in good condition and the repairs as suggested by the Inspector carried out.

The Inspector further states that the teacher requested that one kettle, 45 cups and 45 spoons be supplied for the purpose of preparing and serving hot lunches to the pupils. If you consider this equipment necessary, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of same. The cups and spoons while serviceable should be as inexpensive as possible.

The Inspector states that both the No. 1 and No. 2 Schools should have two coats of paint next summer. I have to request that you will draw this matter to the attention of the Department early next spring, giving full particulars regarding the painting required at each of these schools, the approximate cost of the paints, etc., and the labour, and how you would recommend that the work be carried out.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, relative to the condition of the pump in the well at the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School. It is noted that the pump at present in use is beyond repair and that a new pump is necessary. You may arrange for the purchase and installation of a new pump of a type considered by you to be satisfactory. You should have this new pump installed at an early date, and you should see that it is properly installed. Please keep all expense as low as possible. An account, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the cost of the pump, as well as any expense in having same installed.

Relative to a grant to purchase supplies for a treat to the pupils of both the Nos. 1 and 2 Walpole Island Indian Day Schools, I have to say that our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are extremely limited, and it has been found necessary to reduce the amounts formerly allowed for this purpose. The Department will approve of an expenditure being incurred not exceeding the sum of $20 in the purchase of supplies for a treat to the pupils at the No. 1 School and $10 for the pupils of the No. 2 School. An itemized account, in duplicate, should be obtained covering the cost of the supplies for each school separately. These you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment. It might be advisable for you to consult the teacher as to the supplies required before making the purchase.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

I beg to report on the condition of the steps and platform at the entrance to the two classrooms at the school Walpole Island. We have been making temporary repairs to the step for the past year or two, but the hammer has got so rotten there is nothing to nails two now. Both steps should be replaced with new ones; the ones at the east door are completely gone and the steps at the west door are not quite so bad but should be replaced. The two steps with platforms would probably cost $15.00.

The east step in its present condition is not very safe for the children, they get their feet or legs hurt. However, if we can make it do for a while I will not incur any expense until such time as I hear from the department.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 26th ultimo File No.40-1-5 in reference to repairs at No.1 school. I would beg to say that I have went over these repairs again very carefully, and would say that everything that I ask for in my letter of May 18th is absolutely necessary, with the possible exception of repairs to swings, this is a minor item and should be done before some of the children are hurt.

I might say that the bridge was in such a bad condition that Mr. Alley did think it safe for a car any longer and tore it out and filled the ditch with wood from the school yard. If there should be a heavy rain now there would be no outlet for the water. One of the outside doors is nailed up, as it is too badly damaged to swing, some of the cupboard doors in the school room are off the hinges and apart at the joints. Quite a number of the fence posts are rotted off and before another year the fence will be partly down. I ask for seven new post in the first letter. On going over the fence more carefully find there are 16 new posts needed. In my letter of May the 18th I estimated the cost from $60.00 to $75.00 It is rather doubtful if the needed work can be done for that amount. I estimated the cost of bridge material and labor at $33.25. I have since ask the Wallaceburg lumber company to figure on the cost of bridge. I am enclose there statement for material and labor which is $40.54. A galvanized steel pipe could be used here. A 15 inch pipe 16 ft long would cost for the cheaper grade, 16 gauge steel, at $1.42 a foot, $22.72, and better grade 14 gauge, at $1.62, $25.88. Then there would be the cartage from the Depot and labor putting in. There would not be much difference in the total cost, the steel pipe might be installed at little less cost.

Walpole Island Ont., August 16th 1934.

Sir,

In further reference to your letter of July 4th file NO.40-1-5 "A bridge over ditch in front of NO.1 school.", There are several ways that a bridge could be built for less cost than mentioned, but not a bridge the size that was there formerly. A plank bridge could be narrowed up to probably a width of 4 feet and the sides filled in with dirt. The old bridge was about 8 feet wide, a 4 ft bridge would probably answer the purpose or it could be entirely filled in with dirt at a low cost, but in that case there would be no outlet for the water from the east. There is not such a lot of water here, but in the spring or very wet time the water might flood the school grounds or adjoining lands if there is not some outlet.

Galvanized steel pipes can be purchased from 10 inches up, or 10 in, 12in, 15in, and 18in sizes. I also have here in the yard a 6 in iron pipe that was bought several years ago with road money for use where a small culvert was needed. That might be used at the school. It makes a small outlet for the water and the rest could be filled in with dirt, and the cost would be low if at a later date it was found that it didn't work satisfactory it could be removed and a proper bridge installed. I have not a price list of galvanized steel culvert before me, but 15 in steel culvert cost $1.42 per foot a 12 in. Would probably cost about $1.20 or about $19.20 for a 16 ft culvert, plus labor of installing, cartage from R.R. and possible freight.

There should be something done to replace this bridge before school opens. I can put in this 6 in. iron pipe that is here and fill for probably $10.00 or less. When I estimate $33.00 it was for a finished job.

Dear Sir,

Acting on the advice of Dr. Macdonald I am writing you that the water supply for the school and living quarters are not sanitary. The well is a dug well, perhaps nine feet deep with bricked sides. The top is cement except for the hole where the pump enters. This is big enough for a man to enter when the pump is out.

Nearly every year we have to pump the well dry as the water becomes so strong - cannot use the water, we find dead frogs and turtles pumped out at such times. I believe that if a point was driven down from time to time just below the lower line of the water in the well the water passing through the gravel would be raised. There may however be a better method but I do not know anything should be done as soon as possible.

Sincerely yours,
James H. Bailey
Prin. No. 1 School
Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 24th ultimo, file No. 40-1-5 in reference to the well at No. 1 School, I would like to deal with the wells at both No. 1 & No. 2 schools, as the well at No. 1 school is in better condition than the well at No. 2 school.

I hardly know myself what to report on these wells. If I can secure proper containers I am going to have samples of the water from both the wells at No. 1 and No. 2 School sent to the Provincial Health Department for analysis. I am inclined to think that Mr. Deley's suggestion re-driving a steel point is a good one, but at the present time his well as a whole is in fair condition. I have had new leathers put on the pump this week, and the well pumped dry and cleaned out. With these surfaces weals it seems necessary to clean them once or twice a year to keep the water in good condition, and then it is not number one.

In reference to the well at No. 2 school it is a dug well brick lined, with a concrete top, with a manhole just big enough for a man to get in. When I had a look at it last fall, I found the bricks loose, and every indication of falling in, and it would appear that there is likelyhood of the well caving in. No one cares to go down to the bottom of the well to clean it for fear of a cave in. I have asked a mason to look at the well and give me an estimate cost of the job, but he has not done so at the present time. Some are of the opinion that it would be cheaper to dig a new well than to repair the present well, for to help the repair it would be necessary to break up the concrete top and take the bricks out and replace them, and to make this sort of work it might be necessary to remove a couple of feet of dirt from around the top of the well. This well is approximately 10 ft deep, and of course if this repair was made it would be necessary to build a new concrete top. One would naturally think that both these wells would prevent flies, snakes, and other insects from getting into them, as the manhole is covered with a wooden cover, and the wooden cover has a sheet iron cover sitting over it tight around the pump, despite this flies, snakes, mice, and other insects and animals seem to get into them.
In further reference to driving steel points I might say that many of the summer residents and some of the permanent residents just fasten a steel point, screened, on the end of a pipe and drive them into the ground about 12 to 15 ft until they reach the gravel or quicksand and in this way seem to get all the water required for a house; these wells are considered very sanitary, as no vermin can get into them and there is no body of water to become stagnant. Personally I have had no experience with these wells myself but this morning I was talking to Mr. Bachus, Custom Officer, who drove one at the old custom property 14 years ago and it has never needed any repairs, and is working satisfactory yet. I was also talking to a lady who has had one in her kitchen through the floor 9 years ago, and one outside about 16 years ago and both are working satisfactory, and have never needed any repair. The Anglican rectory has had two drove under the house one five years ago, and one nine, and both still work satisfactory. There is also one under the Parish Hall that is only 4 ft in the ground, and supplied a camp of thirty girls for two months this summer. These points I mentioned are all within 600 feet of the river, and I could not guarantee that they would work at the school, but there seems to be an unlimited supply of water in the dig wells at both schools and I am quite firmly of the opinion that if one struck gravel or quicksand that a point would supply all the water needed for school and residence.

Having no experience I would not care to estimate the cost of these wells with the driven points, but I understand that they cost less than a dug well. I believe that the steel point cost $3.50, and probably 10-15 ft of pipe, depending on the depth necessary to strike gravel, and quite probable the pipe in the present well would do for a driven well. I have been informed that there is an Indian on the reserve here who would drive these wells for $5.00 each, as he had done at the cottages, but as the school is further from the water edge, it may be necessary to drive them a little deeper.

I might say that they are not using water from the well at No. 2 school, but are carrying it from a farm house near by. This well should be attended to at once, but I do not care to authorize the necessary expense until such time as I hear from the Department, and so an early reply would be appreciated. We might be able to drive a point a few feet from the bottom of the present well and fill in with sand or gravel from the river.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 15, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, regarding the wells at the No. 1 and No. 2 Day Schools on Walpole Island.

If you consider that an ample supply of water could be obtained by driving steel points, installing the necessary pipe, pump, etc., the Department will approve of having the work carried out. It is noted that this arrangement for obtaining water has been satisfactory in other cases in the vicinity; but, as the schools are farther from the river than in the cases mentioned by you, it may be necessary to drive the points to a considerably greater depth. You should be in a better position to judge whether this arrangement would be more satisfactory than digging wells, and the Department will have to leave the matter in your hands but will expect you to see that all costs are kept to the lowest possible point. You might advise what action you are taking, and, if possible, give an estimate of the cost involved for each well.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir,

For your information I might say that the roof at the residence at No. 1 School is leaking in places to quite an extent. After it was found to be leaking tar was put on the ground floor, Mr. Bulley and myself went up into the attic and found it leaking many places but not all of them were fixed. There was through to the living quarters, but were running down the walls etc., being absorbed by the plaster in some cases on the ceiling.

This part of the roof is very flat and the shingles have been laid too close to the weather and in general very poorly built; there are many leaky places where the building joins that you can see out any place where you can run your finger out the cracks. On both class rooms the roof has much more pitch and appears to be all right. In the flat part of the residence there are rafters 20 and 22 ft long with out any supports, the center of the roof has lower leaving flats places when a person walks on this it springs so much one would think they were going through. In any case repair I would suggest that there should be some support to put on this long span in the center. The entrance is flat and cover with galvanized material, this year entrance is flat and a heavy coating of roofing tar would stop this.

This roof might be patched, but it would be only a temporary job and not likely to prove satisfactory for any length of time. I had a carpenter look at this roof and submit the following estimate for a new shingle roof, repair to entrance and support to center span:

Halpole Island, Ont.,
Jan. 17, 1938

Dear Mr. Phelan:

When talking with you at the Convention at Mount Elgin Institute, we discussed the noon lunch problem. It seems that we have been busy since, that we got nothing done about it. So after talking it over with Mr. Higfield we decided to tell you our difficulties etc. and get your advice.

There is an enrolment of 75 pupils with an average attendance of 65. This average will probably be lower during the present winter months. So we would need 7 quarts of milk at 10¢ to allow a half cup of milk per pupil. Our plan was to alternate cocoa and creamed vegetable soup. In that case besides the milk we would need sugar, cocoa, vegetables soup bones, barley, etc. I think 20 cents a day for these articles would be sufficient. This would make a total of $1.30 per day.

In regard to equipment we would need a large kettle about $2.50, 2 serving bowls worth 2 large dish pans 4¢ each, 6 dark towels 2 cents each, 6 dog teaspoons and a ring mixing pan and 2 dozen cups. For cooking, we can use our old stove which we use only in summer. We also have an unused cupboard for equipment and a table. The children already own 6 dozen cups.
What would be the system of buying these things, the foodstuffs in particular? Would each person from whom we bought make his own bill or would we use the voucher system?

If we had only cows such days it would consume a lot of time. So let us know what you think of these plans. I would be glad to try it for the next 2 months. I am sure it would be a great help to the children in many ways. It would be good training too, in preparing, serving and cleaning up afterwards.

Trusting that we not, too neat a house for you.

Yours truly,

James H. Daley

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the serving of a midday lunch at the two schools on the Walpole Island Reserve.

While the food served at noon at these schools should be nutritious it is not the Department's intention that a full meal should be supplied as the latter not only means increased expenditure but also extra work and would possibly interfere with the regular school activities.

It has, therefore, been decided to allow $15.00 a month for 4 months at the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School and $3.00 a month for 4 months at the Walpole Island No. 2 school. Accounts should be forwarded at the end of each month and a separate account sent for each school.

Dear Sir:

When Mr. Phelan and Mr. Mo Gookin were here on an official visit in company with former Agent Down, Mr. Phelan told Mr. Down to repair the well at No 1 school. This has not been done and I would like permission to do this now.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant, an amount of $250.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the two schools on the Walpole Island reserve. Please let me know what repairs you consider are required and give an estimate of the cost—it being understood that the total expenditure will not exceed the amount stated above.

Detailed information should be given regarding any material, in order that purchase may be made by our Purchasing Branch, and in the event of Indian labour not being available, you should state the tradesmen required, in order that you may be advised as to who should be employed.

Attention Mr. Phelan

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of June 29 No 40-1-15 re repairs & improvements of Walpole schools, I beg to state that the following estimates for painting by the job for both schools are as follows. No 1 school Labour $120.00 No 2 school $95.00 Total $215.00 Material and labour $310.00 Besides this an entrance on the east side of No 1 school and needed repair to the wall would cost $25.00 to $30.00.

The walls of both schools should be washed. There are several small items need attention at No 2 school. Listed as follows:
Door locks (worn out) Window sash ropes replaced. Small gate n needed. Kitchen stove relined (approved in Mr. Down's time) Valve needed in pump. Blackboards painted. Bridge repaired. Window sash replaced (in residence).

What I would recommend subject of course to the approval of the Dept. is the painting of No 1 school this year as I believe it to be in the worst condition and certainly is in the public eye more than No 2 school. Also that the minor repairs as listed and possibly others that may be found at the time be done as soon as possible. This might take from $200.00 to $225.00. Then if the other school could be painted the next year they should be in good condition.

Materials needed paint, lumber and other builders supplies. Tradesmen needed, painters and carpenters. Some of the work could be done by Indians.

In view of the present world conditions prices may have to be estimated higher.

Hoping to be of further service in this matter.

Your obedient servant

James W. Daley

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with reference to installing an electric lighting plant in the living quarters of the Walpole Island No. 1 school.

The verbal approval of the insurance agent cannot be considered sufficient. The Department would have to have a definite ruling from the insurance company that there would be no increase in rate.

Besides, the whole situation at Walpole Island has not yet been settled and until this is done it is considered very undesirable to install in the school any equipment that might subsequently be removed.

Taking everything into consideration the Department is not prepared at the present time to grant the approval requested in your letter.

DR. McGill,

I beg to submit the following report covering my visit of inspection to the Walpole Island Agency on May 7th and 8th:

School:

No. 1 was visited and Miss Field and Miss Isaac interviewed. School was clean. Out-houses should be supplied with lime. Agent's attention was drawn to the matter. A new door should be built to replace present front door and about one hundred square feet plaster renewed as well as some minor repairs made to outhouses. Estimated cost £35.00. Miss Field the senior teacher is highly regarded throughout the Reserve and appears most satisfactory. Miss Isaac, an Indian girl is also highly regarded and is doing wood work. Attendance has been fairly good.

The school residence a 1½ storey building is in a good state of repair with a single exception. An upstairs bedroom leaks rather badly. The leak said to have existed for twelve years, comes from the flashing at chimney or the chimney itself. Mr. Daly states he has tried to fix the leak and cannot and that the chimney will have to be rebuilt. The chimney is on a bracket. I would recommend that this repair be given attention during the summer and that an expert be asked to quote. After repair has been effected the bedroom should be redecorated.

Dear Sir:

Mrs. Ross, the new Principal of No. 1 Indian Day School, was here and has asked for the following repairs to be made at No. 1 School and in the residence at No. 1 School.

She has asked that the residence be papered throughout and the floor painted in the middle bedroom, a small change made in the kitchen sink, chimneys cleaned, the school rooms entirely cleaned and the walls and woodwork painted, the store rooms and the attics entirely cleaned and the rubbish burned. She would like to purchase for the use in the residence two Aladdin lamps, two new stoves, one for the school and living room, one charcoal iron, china cabinet with drawers for silver. She has particularly asked that the cleaning be done immediately and the papering and painting in the living quarters also be done before school starts. She has also asked that a cement cistern be built in the north east corner of the building outside for soft water. She is also asking that a children's sink be installed in the entry room to the school rooms.

In order to avoid any misunderstanding between her and Miss Faireervice, the other teacher, she would like to have charge of the living quarters and have Miss Faireervice be a boarder. I should recommend this latter request as Mrs. Ross has many friends in the district who will in all probability be visiting her and it would hardly be fair to Miss Faireervice to ask her to pay half of the expenses when the probabilities are that she will have very few friends in this district as she comes from. In regard to the other requests I certainly would like to see her get these things but would draw your attention to the fact that it would cost at least $350 to $400 and frankly this has not been put into the estimate. There is no question about necessity of most of the articles asked for. Some of the things must be done but I am leaving this entirely in your own hands.

Dear Sir:

Resolution 7 Council Meeting Nov. 5, 1941
Re grant for noon lunches at No. 1 School

Mrs. Ross and Mrs. Taylor, teachers at No. 1 School, came to the Council and applied for an additional $10 per month over and above the $15 already approved by your department for noon lunches at No. 1 School.

They assured the Council that this $10 per month over a period of four months was to be used to purchase bread for the children staying for noon. The Council agreed that the benefit to the children would far exceed the amount of money expended and quite willingly granted the request.

I would recommend approval of this and would also respectfully suggest that a grant of $15 should be given No. 2 School for a like purpose. If this could be arranged immediately I am positive that the Council would be only too pleased to pass this resolution at the December Council.

Your obedient servant,

James W. Daley
Indian Agent
Ottawa,
November 15, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant with reference to the serving of a midday lunch at the Walpole Island No. 1 and Walpole Island No. 2 Schools.

With reference to the first paragraph of your letter, I would point out that you have not yet received any authority for expenditure for midday lunch purposes. It is true that you were given authority in the year 1939 but that only covered the academic year 1939-40. Instructions have repeatedly been issued to all Indian Agents that new authority must be obtained in every fiscal year.

If you consider the serving of a midday lunch necessary at these two schools, the Department has no objection to allowing the same monthly amount as previously; namely, $15.00 a month for a period of four months at the No. 1 School and $8.00 a month for a period of four months at the No. 2 School.

We are not prepared to approve the resolution of the Council with reference to expending an additional $10.00 a month from band funds. The Department does not see any necessity for this extra expenditure.

Yours truly,

Mr. Jas. W. Daley,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island, Ont.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, it is difficult for the Department to understand how you consider official letter of September 9, 1941, gave you authority to purchase a $45.00 breakfast set.

My letter of September 9, 1941, was in reply to yours of September 4 in which you specifically mentioned papering and painting and the necessity for some equipment, which did not include a set of dishes.

With reference to the second paragraph of your letter, recording your interview with Mr. Phelan, it is evident that he only told you what you already knew from official letter of September 9. I have consulted Mr. Phelan and he has no recollection whatever of having authorized a set of dishes at the price you paid for them. We try to supply a reasonable amount of dishes for a teacher's residence but certainly the purchase you have made cannot be justified, especially in view of conditions at the present time. Under these circumstances I believe that the set of dishes should be returned.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

There seems to be a mistake regarding the Voucher that I forwarded to you regarding a breakfast set. This breakfast set is not dishes but consisted of a kitchen cabinet, a table and several chairs. I cannot accept the blame for the way that this was entered by the furniture store. Possibly, however, I should have mentioned just what it consisted of.

There was no table in the teacher's residence either in the living room or the kitchen. During the time we taught there we had our own tables and chairs. When Miss Field came as teacher she was granted a certain amount of money to purchase certain needed articles for the residence. She purchased articles for the living room with the money granted. We had a table in the Council Hall here which she made do for the time that she was here. This table did not suit Mrs. Ross who preferred to buy the set as sent in. Re: Pumping School Well

On Sept. 22nd we received a bacteriological report from the Department of Health of Ontario on water samples from our school wells.

No. 1 School - classification of water B
No. 2 School - " " " B

The well at No. 1 School is a dug well, brick lined about 12 feet deep, the cover is quite tight fitting. It would appear that the pollution is from seepage. The toilets are about 125 feet away from the well.

Since the well is full of water I arranged with the chief, fire dept. Wallaceburg to bring a small pump belonging to the Water Works Dept. to the island to pump the well dry.

This was done on Sept. 29th. This pump could not keep up with the rate of seepage long enough to be able to clean the well. To-day the Chief returned with a fire department truck and pumped the well out thoroughly. This pump removed what little extraneous material there was in the well, and we placed in it some water purifier supplied by the water dept. Within half an hour the well was full of water again.

The cost of this operation is high due to the two trips that were made. However it appeared to be the only immediate solution to the problem. I do not know what the source of pollution is unless it is caused from the high water table this year. The well has not been cleaned for several years.

Enclosed please find Mr. Hearn's bill for your consideration.

Albert J. Stallwood, Supt.
Indian Agency.

November 17, 1948.

Dear Mr. Barrett:

I was sorry that I could not get to our Teachers' Convention in Southern Ontario this year but I was in Western Canada inspecting schools at that time.

As you are probably aware, we intend to build an additional classroom or classrooms at Balpole Island next year. Mr. Stallwood has sent me the sketch of the one-room classroom which the Ernest Lumber Company, of Dresden, Ontario, has built in two school sections of Chatham Township in 1938. It would seem that this would be a fairly satisfactory rural school if two windows were placed above the blackboard (to avoid cross light) on the side of the room opposite that with the windows in it.

I note that you have apparently discussed this matter with Mr. Stallwood and are in agreement with this change.

As we are very interested in the construction of one-room schools, I would appreciate any other comments which you would wish to make upon this plan.

With kindest personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

Bernard V. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I am very happy to learn from yours of November 17th, that an extra classroom is to be provided on Walpole Island.

I believe that the room which was designed and built for us by the Bresett Lumber Company of Dresden is as effective and economical as one can get at the present time.

I have not noticed any evidence of cross light in this school but it might be well, if the cost is not too great, to have two Clear-storey windows above the boards on the dark side.

The thing most noticeably wrong with our Chatham Township Schools is the artificial lighting. We have only 4 drops and the last 2 are too close to the back of the room. There should be 6 drops properly spaced over the seating area with 50 watt bulbs along the inside of the room and 300 watt bulbs next to the windows.

You may be certain that I shall be very pleased to do anything which will help your Department in this endeavour.

With very best regards,

Yours sincerely,

F. L. Barrett

Walpole Island Indian Day School.

Reference your 11-40 of May 2

We are quite prepared to erect the new school as outlined in your letter of May 2.

Concerning the extra land required at the site, I would suggest that you write to Mr. L. Brown, Resources and Trustee Division, describing to him the additional land which you feel is required.

In discussing this school with Mr. Doucet, he has suggested that we build, not plan 638, but plan 657, which provides for a full basement. I am therefore sending to you, under separate cover, a set of the drawings for plan 657. The specifications are the same as for 638. You will note that it provides a full basement, which could be used as a lunch-room for the children of all three classrooms at Walpole Island No. 1. The only change necessary would be the installation of a door leading down into the basement so that the children would not have to go through the stair-rooms to reach this basement.

I would like to have, by return mail, your comments as to the advisability of building plan 657 instead of 638. While the former is a more expensive type of building, it might suit your needs better at Walpole Island. The basement, of course, is also available as a second classroom, if and when it is needed. The only concern which I have is whether the land will permit the building of a basement which will be dry at all times of the year.

May 13, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Halpole Island Indian Day School.

Reference your letter received May 12, 1949.

I certainly agree with the suggestion of Mr. Boucet that an additional room be provided that could be used as a lunchroom for the children of all three classrooms at Halpole Island No. 1. In addition, a room would be available as an additional class when necessary.

In most localities this could be ideally located in the basement but I do not wish to recommend this on Halpole Island. The Rectory, parsonage, and its residence each have basements as furnaces, but they are subject to flooding; in the last year, the United Church Board put in a basement to their church but found it too unsatisfactory and have filled it in. The basements mentioned are only approximately four feet below ground level.

It would appear, therefore, that any addition as an education planned would have to be in the form of another room attached to this building.

Robert J. Stallwood,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs.

Memorandum:

DISTRICT OFFICER

Malpole Island Indian Day School.

Last December it was necessary to open a third classroom at the above school in temporary quarters due to our decision to stop sending a number of these children from the island to the Shingwauk Residential School. An investigation had revealed that several children from this reserve were attending this residential school in Sault Ste. Marie and thus preventing other children from Northern Ontario reserves where no day schools were available, from attending this boarding school.

Unfortunately, we were not able to include an amount for the construction of this school in our 1947-50 estimates, but it is our intention to request a transfer of the amount required from the Lake Melan School in the Port Arthur Agency. It does not now seem likely that we will be able to build this latter school as the land on which it will be located is still provincial property and an Indian school can not be located on it. When field officials have settled the matter of this land ownership, we may be able to build the Lake Melan School at a later date.

Therefore, we would request your approval of the attached requisition to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for advertising for tenders for the construction of the standard one-room school at Malpole Island. This building will be directly adjacent to the old building which is a two-room structure.

Our Engineers have advised against adding to
these old schools and recommend that we should erect instead separate buildings in the same playground. It would be appreciated if this requisition could be passed to the Departmental Purchasing Agent when it has received your necessary approval.

Director,

Dear Sir:

Some time ago we received from an Indian Superintendent Agent of Walpole Island, a set of plans and specifications for a one room Indian Day School. We understand from the specifications that we are to tender on a form provided for that purpose. We did not receive this form and our efforts to obtain one from the Superintendent's office at Walpole Island have not been successful.

We believe we have not been placed in a very favourable position in regard to our tender for this work. We do not know what security deposit you require etc. Should it be possible that the contract for this work was arranged previous to us receiving plans, we hope this might receive your attention.

Our estimated cost of this building according to plans and specifications would be seventeen thousand two hundred and twenty three dollars ($17,223). This being a public job, we believe we do have the right to tender as we are well qualified to undertake this class of work.
We are at present constructing three schools in the vicinity of Sarnia, have just completed one a short time ago for the city of Chatham and have on hand at the present time several large commercial projects, one being the Memorial Arena for the city of Chatham, also a building for the Royal Bank of Canada in Sarnia and while we know our tender is possibly irregular, that is through no fault of ours.

Hoping our application for work may be favourably received, we are,

Yours truly,

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a one-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence on the Balpole Island Indian Reserve, Balpole Island Indian Agency, Province of Ontario, for the education of the Indian children living there;

THAT, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

THAT we have received, as a result of these advertisements, the following eight tenders:

Bennett Lumber Company, Dresden, Ontario........... $10,500.00
Ben Brunson, 85 Williams Avenue,
Guelph, Ontario ......................... $10,966.00

G. T. McFarlane, 11 First Street,
Wellandburg, Ontario ................. $11,475.00
Standard Paving and Materials, Limited,
Toronto, Ontario ....................... $12,433.00
Gould Bagn, Park Street, Wellandburg, Ont.... $14,195.00
Curran-Barridge Construction Company, Limited,
Sarnia, Ontario ....................... $17,223.00

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that they comply with the conditions outlined on tender forms which had been prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications.
as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

THAT Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the timber tender, namely that of the Brevoort Lumber Company, Breslau, Ontario, in an amount of Ten Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($10,500.00);

Volume 279, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends the acceptance of the tender of the Brevoort Lumber Company, of Breslau, Ontario, for the erection of this one-room school and teacher's quarters, for the amount of Ten Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($10,500.00).

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Present Lumber Company, Inc., Ontario, hereinafter called "The Contractor", of the first part;

And His Majesty the King, represented by the Minister of Mines and Resources of Canada, hereinafter called "The Minister", of the second part,

HEREAS the party of the first part, for the consideration hereinafter mentioned, has agreed with the party of the second part, to do, furnish and perform the work, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in the manner hereafter described, in connection with the work or works;

NOW THIS AGREEMENT IT IS SEEMS that the said parties hereto, hereby covenant, promise and agree, each with the other as follows:

ARTICLE I. The covenants, clauses, provisions and conditions of the Tender Form, General Instructions to Bidders, and Specifications, (embracing the General Conditions, Labour Conditions, General Specifications and Trade Specifications) together with the drawings and such additional detail drawings, shop drawings and instructions, as may from time to time be furnished, shall be as fully part of this Agreement as if attached hereto, or herein repeated, and should the Contractor or Minister fail to sign them, they shall nevertheless be binding on both parties.

(a) to do, furnish and perform, the works, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in connection with the following work or works namely,

One-room school and attached teacher's residence in accordance with plans and specifications of Plan 888 of the Department of Mines and Resources, on the Walpole Island Indian Reserve at a site to be indicated by the Indian Superintendent, Walpole Island Indian Agency.

(b) to complete substantially, and to the satisfaction of the Minister, all the work, on or before the date or dates following, viz:

the thirty-first day of October, Nineteen Hundred and Forty-Nine.

(c) Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

ARTICLE III: The Minister undertakes and agrees, in consideration of the premises, and subject to the performance and observation on the part of the Contractor, of all covenants, provisos and conditions in the specifications contained;
(a) To pay the Contractor in current funds, for the performance of the contract the sum of Ten Thousand and Five Hundred Dollars ($10,500.00), subject to additions and deductions as provided for in the Specifications governing the work.

(b) To make progress payments on account thereof, as provided for in the Specifications, equal to ninety per cent (90%) of the value, proportionate to the amount of the Contract, of labour and materials incorporated into the work, as estimated by the Engineer, less the aggregate of previous payments.

(c) On completion of the entire work, and on full performance of the covenants and clauses of the Specifications, to make full payment of the balance due under the Contract, as set out in the Specifications.

ARTICLE IV: The Contractor and the Minister for themselves, their successors, executors, administrators and assigns, hereby undertake and agree, to the full performance of the covenants contained herein.

Re: New Classroom No. 1 Indian Department,
Walpole Island Indian Reserve

The contractor is giving permission for Miss McKenna to move into the new quarters on Saturday October 29th, 1949. Insofar as the residence is concerned the contractor is finished, with the exception of sanding and varnishing the floors. The hardwood flooring is good material but it was not well enough finished at the mill to be able to sand by hand. Consequently they require sanding with electrical equipment. Since it is not possible to obtain electrical power for that purpose on the Island, the contractor is willing to shellac the floors now and to do the sanding and finishing next year if and when the hydro service is extended to the Island. An amount to cover this work will be deducted from the contract price and the final payment requested when the work is completed.

Regarding the classroom, the contractor has been notified that the blackboards will be shipped to arrive November 7th. With the exception of the floors as mentioned above all the work will be completed by that time and the classroom will be ready for use.

May authority be given please to purchase locally 8 standard size blinds and 3 small blinds for classrooms and 5 standard blinds for residence @ $1.50 per blind. Total cost $24.00.

Reference our letter of September 28, 1949. May we be advised please regarding the type of heater that will be purchased for the teachers residence.

Finally, Miss McKenna wishes a kitchen table. A quotation by Douglas-Haycock for a table, 28" x 42" top, is $9.50. May authority be given please to purchase this locally.

R.J. Stallwood, Superintendent,

The Deputy Supt. General,

Mr. D. A. Gordon, M.P., of Wallaceburg, asks the Department's consent to the erection of a house on Walpole Island for Miss Cameron, who has been appointed teacher of No. 1 school. You will see that Miss Cameron's brother would bear the expense and an Indian locatee is willing to give the site.

This would appear to be a very satisfactory arrangement and, if it were not for information on file regarding Miss Cameron, I would recommend its being carried out.

Miss Cameron was appointed through the good offices of Mr. Gordon and it was only after her appointment that the Department became aware of the fact that it was placing the school in charge of an old and infirm woman. Mr. Agent McDougall says that her health and age are against her. She is fully sixty years old, if not older, and, although, as far as her education is concerned she is capable of teaching, she is not a qualified teacher, and former teachers were dissatisfied for this cause. I have reasons to know that the Indians are dissatisfied with the appointment and as her retaining the position as dependent upon her giving satisfaction, I think it would be unwise to give her any hold on the
school such as the proposed arrangement would confer.

If you agree with me, Mr. Gordon could be told that a surrender would have to be obtained from the band before a lease could issue. This is the strictly legal process that should be followed, although in some exceptional cases the Department has given a permit.

I have to submit the following report on the school at Walpole Island for 1927.

I had been asked to visit the No. 1 school and proceeded there from the Parish Hall. This school is in charge of two teachers, mother and daughter, there being two classrooms. The living accommodation for two teachers is far from satisfactory. The building was very poorly planned in the first instance and if our present staff consist of mother and daughter I am sure their condition sooner or later will be unpleasant conditions. As it is, it presents the only living and dining room they have is an extension of a hallway which divides the two classrooms.

More inadequate accommodation would be hard to find. Cooking is also done in this hallway. Two bedrooms are upstairs and the stairway occupies the front part of the hall. An extension could easily be built on the back of the school, of two stories which would increase the accommodation and with some minor alterations in layout provide adequate quarters for two teachers.

We cannot always expect to have our present staff there and even were this possible it is unfair to ask them to continue living under such circumstances. I would strongly recommend that steps be taken to put an addition on the rear of the school building and alter the layout accordingly in order that adequate quarters may be available for two people.

As the winter season approaches, we are anxious to know that the new building for the Indians will be completed in time to build. Should be started as soon as possible.

All plans have been approved by the various contractors whom Mr. Paul, the Indian Agent, has brought to give estimates. We are now in receipt of a written estimate from Mr. Paul.

The plans are coming along, and a reliable firm from which to purchase the materials needed for the school has been located. The workmen are very satisfied and the work will be able to start immediately. Waiting for other contractors to submit plans which are not at all come within the amount allowed, only seems to be wasting time. The plans are being forwarded under separate cover also.

Following our conversation with you re., our warrant officer being unsatisfactory, we wrote to Mr. Paul, requesting that he visit the Indian Constable to report in the office. In present circumstances, Mr. Allan Grace is a Polychrome Indian, hence does not receive favourably by the Chiefs and Chipewa. He is quite frequently intoxicated and does not visit the schools regularly. Mr. Paul says he has not forwarded this request to you.

Specifications Covering Addition to Walpole Island School #1.

**Foundation Work:**

For foundation - excavate to depth of 16" around entire building and mix 5 parts of clean river gravel to 1 part of cement, and bring foundation up to the height of wall in the present building.

Build brick chimney on platform with 8 x 8 flue, to height shown on plan.

**Carpenter Work:**

All material for frames and all finish lumber must be dry and suitable for purpose it is to be used.

All joisting, studding, rafters etc., to be of standard 2" (thickness) hemlock or its equal.

**Joists:**

Joists in both floors are to be of 2 x 8 - 14 ft. placed at 16" centres with one row of herringbone bridging.

**Studs:**

All studs, joists and rafters are to be placed at 16" centre and firmly spiked.

**Cornice:**

The cornice is to be of white pine and to match with present building.

**Windows:**

All windows are casement frames and sash to be hung with loose pin butts and fasteners on inside.

**Sub Floor:**

Sub floor to be of white pine DLS. firmly nailed at all bearing points.

All outside lining on walls to be of #1 quality of shiplap.

There is to be one thickness of heavy asphalt felt over shiplap, and then to be covered with ½ x 5 or 1½ x 6, Red Cedar Lap siding.

**Roof:**

The entire roof is to be sheathed with white pine sheathing DLS, and covered with 3½ Med Cedar Shingles every course nailed, 3 ply paper & shiplap inside.

(to be used from save of present dormer over new part)

**Inside:**

The entire walls and ceilings are to be covered with Gyproc and all joists covered with a strip ¾ x 1¼ to give same a panel effect.

All openings are to be cased with B.C. fir and back hand trim neatly put on.
Finished floors both upstairs and down are to be B. C. Fir, 7/8 x 3½ face with a thickness of waterproof paper between sub floor and top floor downstairs.

Back Porch:
The present back porch is to be moved as shown on plan and put up over new outside door.

Stairs:
The present door and window downstairs are to be changed. The door is to be placed where the window now is, and the window where the door is.

There is to be a door put where the one window in the dormer now is so as to make an entrance to the new part.

Anything not shown on plans or not particularly specified is not part of the contract.
Jama, Ontario.

While at Walpole Island last week the agent brought to my attention the drainage condition at one of his schools in the village where there is absolutely no plumbing fixtures of any kind. The waste water from the kitchen and elsewhere is thrown out in front of the kitchen entrance, this being unsatisfactory during summer months. These conditions can be remedied by the installation of an enamel iron sink 30" x 20" underneath the stairs in the kitchen, also a hand pump which can be connected to the water well outside the building. The waste water from the above mentioned sink can be disposed of by building a cess pool at a distance of sixty feet from the building connected to the house by a four inch vitrified drain pipe with a ventilator placed on it before it enters the building. If granted this work can be carried out by the Indian Agent at a cost not exceeding $10.00.

The attention of the Department has lately been brought to the present drainage conditions existing at the village school at Walpole Island, which was lately visited by an officer of this Department, and it was suggested that the present conditions can be remedied by the installation of an iron sink 30" x 20" underneath the stairs in the kitchen also a hand pump which can be connected to the water well outside the building. Dear Sir:

We are just in receipt of your letter of the 24th inst., with reference to #49-18 "Colonist Banner" in which the oven front has been burned through on account of the back lining having been removed from the firebox.

It is quite a job to replace this part, as it really involves dismantling the stove.

A better proposition would be for you to get a piece of steel of the proper size and bolt it over the part that is damaged on the inside of the oven, filling in the space with stove cement. If you will do this, and then put the linings back in the stove, you may still get a good deal of service from it. Any tinsmith could fix up a piece of sheet metal for you, or if there is not a tinsmith with the proper material available, you might send us a paper template showing the shape and size of the part needed, and we would, of course, be glad to fix up a piece of sheet metal for you here. You will then have to drill a few holes in the stove to fasten it in place, of course, but no doubt you have breast irons or electric drills that you can use. If the back lining has been removed and lost, we can supply you with another upon receipt of your instructions. If you order a back lining, please be sure to advise us whether the bottom of the firebox consists of a pair of duplex grates on which either coal or wood can be burned, or if it is fitted with a flat grate for wood burning only.

Yours truly,

In accordance of Mr. Indian Agent Wrightfield who is at present on his holidays I am submitting, direct to you, a requisition for floor coverings for the kitchen and living room of the Kindergarten at our school.

The kitchen is 5' x 4' yds by 4' yds = 23 sq. yds at a cost of $1.38 a sq. yd. = $31.74

He has, however, failed to deal with the points made by Mr. Sampson in his letter, in which he claims that Ohonee, who is the instigator of this petition, is actuated by spite and that some of the signers of the petition have no children of school age, only four out of the eight having children attending the school.

Mr. Sampson has been teaching this school for the past fourteen years. The Department is aware that he has no special qualifications and possibly a change would be advantageous. Mr. Conn, Public School Inspector, who visited
visited this school on the 1st of October, last, in his report in speaking of Sampson states "success only fair, but I think his work is improving and the pupils are making somewhat better progress in their studies".

It would be a difficult matter to obtain a qualified, white teacher for this school, as in the No. 1 School they have had seven teachers in the last four years and the present teacher has sent in her resignation. As Sampson has been so long in the employ of the Department I do not think it would be just to him to dismiss him summarily. Mr. McCallum will have to take steps to secure a qualified teacher for the No. 1 School and I think before doing anything with the No. 2 School we might wait to see what success he has. At any rate I would not advocate dispensing with Mr. Sampson's services till the end of the school year.
