Sir,

Your letter of Jan 23rd, no. 152943-1 received. I could not reply sooner as I wished to see the agent Mr. McCallum before I wrote. I went down to see him last Sunday but he was not at home; then followed a big storm and the roads were a mass of snow and mud. The round trip from the schoolhouse to the agent's residence at the front and back to my place is nearly six miles so could not go down till last evening.

Now I wish to say here that if my remarks are a little vigorous it is without prejudice toward the Indian Department as I appreciate the courteous consideration you have given me during the past seven years.

Now I respectfully, but emphatically, beg to say that any report you may have that states that my health is not of the best is an absolute falsehood. My age I cannot deny and don't
wish to. I have never had better health in my life than I have at present and I have always had good health. I could show you the amount of work I have done during the last autumn in gathering a small wood in the woods and carrying it in bundles about a quarter of a mile to my house for my winter's supply of fuel.

As regards my school work I have received compliments indirectly from those most interested, on my efforts to teach the children the English language which has not been done by previous teachers, at least not for a few years past.

I don't know how many are in the plot against me but I do know the instigator of the whole thing, "and thereby hangs a tale." I am the victim of a vile plot. I could tell the whole story but I am not
pleading to stay here only as I shall state shortly. I don't mind the dismissal so much as I do the manner in which it has been brought about by an enemy in the camp.

Now I would respectfully ask for one last favor from the Department. I live alone in a rented log house about 14 miles from the settlement. It is difficult to get supplies as it is about seven miles to Wallaceburg and I have to hire a rig when I go there. It is difficult to get a conveyance and when one does so the Indians consider a white man as their lawful prey so far as money is concerned. Because of these difficulties I have laid in my winter stock of eatables such as potatoes, bacon, apples (that grow on the place), sugar, tea, coffee, flour etc. I have also a big pile of wood referred to above.
which is unsuitable but which serves me well as it is dry and small for my little stand. Now because of these facts, I esteem it a great favor if you could, or rather would, let me stay on till the summer holidays when I shall bid the schoolhouse farewell forever.

In the mean time, this place is a sea of mud. Even I have some things I must dispose of—a stone table, bedstead and mattress, tools, nails etc.

Another reason I have is, I may stay here awhile after the school closes, and have some of my family come up from there to stay awhile.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 7th, 1929.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Walpole Isld. Agency.

No. 2 school is in charge of Mrs. Edith E. George who has only a commercial certificate but has twenty-five years' teaching experience. There are thirty-eight pupils on the roll. Attendance is reported as very good and progress fair. Besides the regular curriculum the pupils are taught knitting, sewing, mending, dressmaking and manual training. The classroom was clean and well ventilated. The teacher's residence attached was very tidy and well kept and reflects great credit upon Mrs. George.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.

We, the undersigned do herein make the following complaints, against Miss Ethel George, the school teacher of No. 2 School of Wapole Island.

Sir:

The Department has received a further communication from Allan Isaac, relative to the complaints made by him regarding the teacher of the Walpole Island No. 2 Indian Day School. He states that she continues to show discrimination against his children, and that she has reported them as being absent from school when they were in attendance. He also states that the teacher sends his children home at three o'clock, while she keeps the other children in school until the regular closing period.

I have to request that you will arrange at your earliest convenience to interview both Allan Isaac and the teacher with a view to straightening out any difficulty there may be between them. This man should understand that it is expected his children will attend school regularly and comply in all respects with the regular discipline. You should also inform the teacher that it is expected she will see that no discrimination is exercised by her against any of the pupils who attend. The Department desires that the frequent complaints of Allan Isaac will cease, and you should use every endeavour to smooth out any difficulties there may be between the teacher and himself.

Please inform the Department of the result of any action taken by you in the matter; also inform Allan Isaac that his communication has been received by the Department and that you have been instructed to deal with the matter of the complaints made by him.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from Mrs. George, teacher of the Walpole Island No. 2 Indian Day School, regarding a pupil, George Isaac, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Isaac. The Department has noted the trouble this boy has occasioned and the difficulty the teacher has had with him and his father.

It is considered that action should be taken to prevent Allan Isaac interfering with the classroom work and discipline of the school. You may, therefore, in conjunction with the R.C.M.P., lay a charge against Allan Isaac, provided that, after due warning, he does not cease his interference with the work of the school and annoying the teacher. He should be made to understand that his son is to be amenable to the discipline of the school and is to conduct himself properly in the classroom. It is necessary that Mrs. George be protected in her duties as teacher and that all pupils comply with the discipline of the classroom.

The Department does not consider it advisable to have the boy placed in a reform school. We regret that at the present time there is no vacancy in any of our residential schools in which he could be placed.

Sir,

Re-Schools.

For your information I would beg to say that owing to the death of Mrs. Ethel George father there was no school at No.2 school from Tuesday Feb.24 to Monday Feb.27 being closed 4 days the 21,22,23,24.

Mrs. James Daly teacher in the Junior room at No. school, owing to illness was not able to teach Thursday or Friday the 23 and 24. This morning Dr. Rowland said it would be necessary for Mrs. Daly to remain in bed another two day and that she should not teach again this week. What are the regulations on the reserves in respect to day allowed teacher under pay for time lost for illness? There are qualified teacher available here now, I suggested to Mr. Daly that he secure one of these teacher to take charge of Mrs. Daly's room for a week. Mr. Daly did not care to do so and become responsible for the pay, and I felt that the Department would not care to pay two teacher for the same room.

What would be the Department wish if Mrs. Daly sickness should be extended for a longer time or in the future if a similar case should arise.

Section 103 sub-section (4) of the provincial school act said in part:- Every teacher shall be entitled to his salary notwithstanding his absence from duty on account of sickness for a period not exceeding four weeks in any one year of his employment if the sickness is certified to by a Physician.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, March 4, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, informing the Department that, owing to the death of her father, Mrs. George closed the No. 2 School, Walpole Island, for a period of four days; also that Mrs. James Daley, teacher of the junior room at the No. 1 School, would not be able to teach for a period of over a week owing to illness.

When it is necessary for a teacher to be absent for a few days on account of illness or for family reasons, school will have to remain closed. Should it be necessary for a teacher to be absent for any lengthy period, the matter should immediately be reported to the Department, stating the probable length of such absence. When, if considered necessary, authority will be given to obtaining the services of a substitute. When a teacher is absent for a period of over five days on account of illness, a doctor's certificate should be forwarded, in order that salary can be paid.

As Mrs. Daley will, no doubt, be able to resume duties at an early date, it will not be necessary to obtain a substitute. If Mr. Daley cannot arrange to take a number of the junior pupils into his room, the junior room will have to remain closed until Mrs. Daley is able to resume duties.

Your obedient servant,
